etymologies: mid 17th century; earliest use found in Robert Vilvain (d. 1663), physician and philanthropist. From im- + perspicuous, after classical Latin imperspicuus not clear, obscure

definitions: Not clearly expressed or easily understood; obscure, opaque; (of a speaker or writer) unclear in style, meaning, or expression. Occasionally also of an object: †not transparent or translucent; compare "perspicuous" (obsolete).
